title: Arbitrary Code Injection in ownCloud’s Windows Client

profile.name: ownCloud
profile.about: ownCloud GmbH is the company behind the ownCloud Project - the most downloaded open source project for data and file sync, share and view.

vulnerability_information:
The current ownCloud Windows Desktop client is prone to an arbitrary code injection vulnerability.

The underlying issue is that the ownCloud desktop client tries to load QT extensions from C:\usr\i686-w64-mingw32\sys-root\mingw\lib\qt5\plugins.

As any authenticated user on Windows is allowed to create new folders within C:, the expected folder structure can be created.

What that means is that a local attacker can create a malicious QT extensions that gets automatically loaded on the next launch of the ownCloud Desktop client.

To verify the issue I first tried to simply create a new QT imageformats plugin. However I failed! Have you ever tried to install QT? So I decided to simply modify an existing DLL.

Hence, I used Hopper to disassemble the qwindows.dll platform’s library to learn more about its entry points. With that knowledge I planned to modify the DLL so that it shows a simply message box. The necessary shellcode was created with Metasploit:

msfvenom -a x86 --platform windows -p windows/messagebox TEXT="DLL Loaded" EXTIFUNC=process -f raw > shellcode
cat shellcode |xxd -p

I then overwrote some bytes after one of the previously identified DLL entry points with the shellcode.

After placing the modified payload DLL into C:\usr\i686-w64-mingw32\sys-root\mingw\lib\qt5\plugins\platforms the shellcode got executed after launching the ownCloud desktop client.

Please see the attached PDF for some images documenting the process.
Furthermore I created a private screen capture: https://owncloud.bogner.sh/s/Ik8AYJ9FfY5Rkyq
vulnerability_information_html:
The current ownCloud Windows Desktop client is prone to an arbitrary code injection vulnerability.

The underlying issue is that the ownCloud desktop client tries to load QT extensions from C:\usr\i686-w64-mingw32\sys-root\mingw\lib\qt5\plugins.

As any authenticated user on Windows is allowed to create new folders within C:, the expected folder structure can be created.

What that means is that a local attacker can create a malicious QT extensions that gets automatically loaded on the next launch of the ownCloud Desktop client.

To verify the issue I first tried to simply create a new QT imageformats plugin. However I failed! Have you ever tried to install QT? So I decided to simply modify an existing DLL.

Hence, I used Hopper to disassemble the qwindows.dll platform’s library to learn more about its entry points. With that knowledge I planned to modify the DLL so that it shows a simply message box. The necessary shellcode was created with Metasploit:

msfvenom -a x86 --platform windows -p windows/messagebox TEXT="DLL Loaded" EXTIFUNC=process -f raw > shellcode
cat shellcode |xxd -p

I then overwrote some bytes after one of the previously identified DLL entry points with the shellcode.

After placing the modified payload DLL into C:\usr\i686-w64-mingw32\sys-root\mingw\lib\qt5\plugins\platforms the shellcode got executed after launching the ownCloud desktop client.

Please see the attached PDF for some images documenting the process.
Furthermore I created a private screen capture: https://owncloud.bogner.sh/s/Ik8AYJ9FfY5Rkyq

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us. We take security very seriously and would appreciate if you would not share any information about this bug until we have determined a potential patch.
 
Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us. We take security very seriously and would appreciate if you would not share any information about this bug until we have determined a potential patch.

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster.

activities.message:
While we wait: Can you still reproduce if you put a file called `qt.conf` next to `owncloud.exe` with the following contents:

```
[Paths]
Prefix = .
Plugins = .
Binaries = .
Imports = .
Qml2Imports = .
LibraryExecutables = .
```
activities.markdown_message:
While we wait: Can you still reproduce if you put a file called qt.conf next to owncloud.exe with the following contents:

[Paths]

Qml2Imports = .
LibraryExecutables = .

activities.message:
Hi, 

Yes after this change the DLL is not loaded anymore. However there is still one suspicious CreateFile operation on C:\usr\i686-w64-mingw32\sys-root\mingw\etc\pki\tls\openssl.cnf (see attached file).

After a quick look over the man page (http://www.tldp.org/LDP/solrhe/Securing-Optimizing-Linux-RH-Edition-v1.3/chap24sec194.html) this file may - depending on the actual source - allows a local attacker to modify the OpenSSL configuration. Thereby it might be possible to tamper the encrypted HTTPS communication channel with the ownCloud server for all local users.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

Yes after this change the DLL is not loaded anymore. However there is still one suspicious CreateFile operation on C:\usr\i686-w64-mingw32\sys-root\mingw\etc\pki\tls\openssl.cnf (see attached file).

After a quick look over the man page (http://www.tldp.org/LDP/solrhe/Securing-Optimizing-Linux-RH-Edition-v1.3/chap24sec194.html) this file may - depending on the actual source - allows a local attacker to modify the OpenSSL configuration. Thereby it might be possible to tamper the encrypted HTTPS communication channel with the ownCloud server for all local users.

activities.message: http://dl-oc.owncloud.com/desktop/daily/ownCloud-2.2.3.6300-nightly20160805-setup.exe has the good fix. Please try either that or RC1 which we are going to release later today. I cannot see any of the C:\usr\... pathes in procmon anymore.
activities.markdown_message: http://dl-oc.owncloud.com/desktop/daily/ownCloud-2.2.3.6300-nightly20160805-setup.exe has the good fix. Please try either that or RC1 which we are going to release later today. I cannot see any of the C:\usr... pathes in procmon anymore.

activities.message:
Hi,
Yes looks good. That was a quick fix ;-)

As I want to publish a blog post about this issue I want to know if it's OK for you if I release it alongside your 2.2.3 release? Is there already a planed release date?

Does this bug qualify for a bounty? (https://owncloud.com/owncloud-bug-bounty-program/)

Kind regards

activities.message:
About your points:

1. Well, yes, We had 2.2.3 coming up anyway and it would have been sad to release 2.2.4 just for this. :)
2. We usually give our users a two weeks opportunity to update before we publish security details. So it would be nice if you could wait until we publish the advisories after those two weeks.
3. Yes it does, even though after discussion with the colleagues we would rate it as "Low". Reason: Users will need to be admins to write to `C:`. Unless you assume malice in the family on a shared machine, this is usually not a problem. In companies, users without admin privs cannot get past UAC to write to arbitrary `C:` locations.

I hope this works for you. Please let me know how you would like to be credited.
activities.markdown_message:
About your points:

  1. Well, yes, We had 2.2.3 coming up anyway and it would have been sad to release 2.2.4 just for this. :)
  2. We usually give our users a two weeks opportunity to update before we publish security details. So it would be nice if you could wait until we publish the advisories after those two weeks.
  3. Yes it does, even though after discussion with the colleagues we would rate it as "Low". Reason: Users will need to be admins to write to C:. Unless you assume malice in the family on a shared machine, this is usually not a problem. In companies, users without admin privs cannot get past UAC to write to arbitrary C: locations.

I hope this works for you. Please let me know how you would like to be credited.

activities.message:
Hi,
1 + 2.) Great - I will wait for that
3.) I'm pretty sure that normal users are allowed to append new folders to C:. Please see the attached screenshot for the corresponding ACLs of my clean Windows 7 x64. Additionally, there is also no UAC dialog (as seen in the initial video).  Hence, any local user is able to carry out this attack. Thereby I think it should be classified more severe.

activities.message: Ok, I'll double check next week. If so, I agree!

activities.message: This is even true for Windows 2008 R2. (I don't have access to other systems right now but I expect ever Windows OS to be vulnerable to this attack)

activities.message:
Sorry for catching up so late. Yes, I have double checked. Your contribution is eligible for a bounty. We have assigned this issue MEDIUM priority as per our definition on the bounty program, consistent with our program criteria at https://hackerone.com/owncloud. The total payout will thus be $100.

I am currently writing up an advisory which I plan to send your for review (still today). Could still wait until its published?

activities.message:
Here it goes: https://staging.owncloud.org/security/advisory/?id=oc-sa-2016-016.

Note the following: https://nvd.nist.gov/cvss.cfm says "1. Vulnerabilities are labeled "Low" severity if they have a CVSS base score of 0.0-3.9."  So maybe we should reconsider the Medium evaluation, Unless you do not agree with the SVSS formula. 

Note: We will pay out a 100 USD reward anyway, even if the final rating is low, because your report is outstanding, as has been the communication with you.
activities.markdown_message:

Note: We will pay out a 100 USD reward anyway, even if the final rating is low, because your report is outstanding, as has been the communication with you.

activities.message:
Great thanks! You really take security seriously! It was a real pleasure to work with you guys! 

Regarding the CVSS Score: I think the Exploitability rating should be "Functional exploit exists" as the available exploit works very reliable ( I can't think of a reason why it should fail to be honest). The currently selected "POC" is defined as "works most of the time" or "needs modification". Please hover the items in the "Temporal Score Metrics" section for more information (Unfortunately I'm unable to copy the text from the webpage ;-)

This leads me to a 4.1 MEDIUM rating: https://nvd.nist.gov/cvss.cfm?calculator&version=2&vector=(AV:L/AC:M/Au:S/C:C/I:P/A:N/E:POC/RL:OF/RC:C) 

So I think we should stick with it. What do you think?

activities.message: I agree. I have updated the advisory accordingly. I've also contacted MITRE to issue a CVE based on our advisory.
